newsitem.title: CHINA: Shenzhen B shares end up on interim expectations.
newsitem.headline: Shenzhen B shares end up on interim expectations.

text.p: Shenzhen's hard currency B share index reversed morning losses to close higher on Thursday due to selective demand for stocks expected to post satisfactory 1997 interim results, brokers said.
The index gained 0.91 points or 0.68 percent to 133.64 points after hitting an intraday low of 132.22 on turnover of HK$46 million, compared with Wednesday's HK$39 million.

The domestic A share index advanced 5.54 points or 1.35 percent to 415.13 points due to institutional buying, brokers said. Turnover in the A share market was 6.8 billion yuan agianst 7.1 billion on Wednesday.
"Buying was focused on stocks likely to generate good interim results," an analyst at a major Chinese brokerage said.
Investors were paying more attention to first-half earnings during the 1997 interim corporate reporting season which would end on August 30, analysts said.
Many, however, refrained from heavy trading, they said.
An article published in China's Business News on Wednesday said Chinese investors should be wary of the interim results because they were unaudited and did not represent a full year's performance.
The Guotai analyst said the B share index had entered a period of consolidation.
Analysts said they expected the B share index to trend higher on Friday after mild corrections for two straight sessions.
In the B share market, Nanjing Posts & Telecommunications Co Ltd rose HK$0.12 to HK$3.70 on volume of 1.37 million shares, making it the second most actively traded stock.
Investors expected robust interim profits from the company, brokers said.
Newcomer Beijing Yanjing Brewery Co Ltd, which listed 72 million A shares on Wednesday, surged 1.52 yuan to its 10 percent limit-up at 16.72 yuan on Thursday.
Volume reached 19 million shares, making it the most actively traded A share.
Brokers said investors snapped up Yanjing, China's biggest brewery, because they were optimistic about the company's outlook.
